none: Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.). School of Music (Contributor)
Northwestern University Video Cassette Collection--Northwestern University Marching Band Highlights
Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.). School of Music

Highlights from the Northwestern University Marching Band performances during the 1985 season. Selections include the pregame performance from a game between the Northwestern Wildcats and the Iowa Hawkeyes featuring "Go U Northwestern" and "Wildcat Fantasy." A performance of "You're a Grand Old Flag" and "Yankee Doodle Dandy" as part of a tribute to Indiana Hoosiers. The Northwestern Homecoming performances include "Sing, Sing, Sing," Don Owens conducting the Vocal Jazz Ensemble in "Birdland," and the NUMB alums joining the marching band for "Bill Bailey Won't You Please Come Home." Another halftime performance features "My Kind of Town," "Tiger of San Pedro," and "New World Symphony." Performances from parent weekend features songs by George and Ira Gershwin including "Summertime," "Man I Love," "I've Got Rhythm," and "Rhapsody in Blue." Performances from the game against the Fighting Illini include "Go U Northwestern," "Wildcat Fantasy," "Yankee Doodle Dandy," "You're a Grand Old Flag," "Georgia on My Mind," and "Sing, Sing, Sing." John P. Paynter then conducts the band in "Alma Mater" and the finale "March of the Steelmen." Rehearsal performances in Dyche Stadium follow the highlights.

The recordings on this web site are provided for use by Northwestern University students, faculty, staff and guests. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of these recordings from this site is strictly prohibited. Please contact specialcollections@northwestern.edu for more information
Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections API
Homepage at Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections

Digitization of this collection was funded by a generous gift from the family of Music professor and bandleader John Phillip Paynter, who began his musical studies at Northwestern, graduating with a Bachelor of Music degree in 1950 and a Master's in Theory and Composition in 1951. Upon graduation, Paynter joined NU's faculty as the Director of the Marching Band. During his career at Northwestern, Paynter taught classes in band music, conducting, and arranging.
